blogPost.title: Nextgen Technology Trends HR Will Need To Adapt To
blogPost.content:
Gone are the days when we inserted thick cards into machines for in-out time tracking. Then came fingerprint scanners that were used in all walks of life, and now it is our retina's that are scanned. Thus, it won't be wrong to say that technology has taken over all domains to make life easier. HR is no different. In fact, PeopleStrong says, 'Indian companies can save at least $600m annually by 2021 using HR Technology.'

 

So, what are the nextgen technology trends that organizations will need to adapt to, and HR will have to pay the way for?

 

  1. The bubble called Cloud — With everything moving on to a virtual platform, it is imperative for HR to keep most data on the cloud for real-time use, primarily since the millennials and the GenZ will dominate the next generation. They are dominated by the need to work from anyplace-anywhere-anytime, and it will be essential to move everything to the cloud for instant on-demand use. 
     
  2. AI augmentation — Increasing technology use is not enough. It is important to use it smartly to achieve target-oriented business impact. With augmented AI, analytics will be sharper and decision making stronger. With AI-enabled data on skillsets vs job descriptions, HR will be able to hire the right mix of candidates who could benefit the organization in the long run. With the use of AI in analyzing employees' career goals, HR could address their learning and development needs preparing them for a bright future. 
     
  3. BYOD - With the invasion of multiple digital devices, data and device security are becoming an essential aspect of IT and HR teams. The future will see HR asking employees to bring their own devices as they would be unwilling to sync their professional and personal lives on company-owned devices. This will also reduce dependency on company-owned devices leading to business benefits.
     
  4. Tech for gig & Hybrid — Organizations are moving towards gig economies and hybrid working where it will be crucial for organizations to provide round-the-clock technology solutions for accessibility if not availability.
     
  5. IoT in HR: With remote working and the rise of the gig economy, HR may feel the need to adopt wearables to track time, monitor health, fitness etc., with cloud-based services in a secure ecosystem.

Source: PeopleMatters
